title: From OCW to MOOC: Deployment of OERs in a massive open online course. The experience of Universidad Carlos III de Madrid

author: Susan Webster, Universidad Carlos III de Madrid

segmentation: So I'm here to talk to you about our experience at University.

That character thorough in converting a widely disseminated or CW course into MC, and this is allowed us to analyze the difficulties we came across in the process and also consider strategies for successfully carrying out such a change.
So first of all, I'll give you some background information.

In my University, our open education policies and will look at some open education milestones and then will develop it on the open courseware model and our open courseware project, particularly some administrative law courses.
And then we'll do a comparison of both models, or CW and MC, and then we look at the transit from an OSW tamuk and the resulting administrative law MC.
And then I'll end with some conclusions.
So my University is relative knew it was established in 1989.
We have three campuses doing small towns to the South of the capital, gold for Taffy, Leganes and one to the North corner echo.

We have 3 academic and research centers, Faculty of Humanities, communication library, science, Faculty of Law and social Sciences, and the School of Engineering that offer a wide range of degrees at both undergraduate and graduate level.
We have 1900 faculty members, 700 people on administrative staff in the student population of around 19,000.
And so, um, the open education guidelines apart of our universities philosophy, sharing, reducing barriers and increasing access to education.
An there are a couple of circumstances at my University that has helped to foster the creation of open courses.

First of all, the broad experience of our professors over more than a decade in digitizing their teaching materials to to put them online for the students on their open on the virtual learning platform, and then the change in the teaching and learning methodology brought about by the new programs that had to be designed according to the Bologna process, to adapt them to the European Higher Education Area.
So open courseware was actually the first open Education Initiative initiative launched at my University in 2006, when the movement reached Spain under the auspices of University.
Then the following year we set up our open Archive, which is indirectly we could save related to open educational resources or open education.
Whose name, of course, is to collect, store, and preserve the intellectual production of our professors.

More recently, we've set up two important working groups, Maria, which stands for multimedia and Open Cage, open educational resources, and this group is composed of professors, library staff, and people from the computing service that are specialists in intellectual property rights, Open Access and quality, open educational resources, and the aim of this group is to divine define policies.
And strategies for designing, creating and managing quality oers and then the unit for educational turn technology and innovating.

Innovative teaching, which has a more practical focus composed of again staff from the library service and the computing service and our aim is to help teachers to use educational technologies to create open educational resources.
And we also evaluate platforms and tools.
Ann, for course.
Design, content creation and student evaluation.
Then in 2013, we saw the launch of the media, the X MOOC platform by University, and Telefonica Learning Services, and that enabled us to launch our first MC's.
And just this year, the beginning of this year we've actually joined the Edx consortium and we have the commitment to put up for books on this platform.
By the beginning of next year and all these open education and IT initiatives are available on our website under Digital Dot UC3 m.es.

So looking at the open courseware model as we know, it's basically a repository of teaching materials that are the materials that teachers use in their on campus classes and they adapt them to the open courseware platform and philosophy.
So basically this is a self learning process.
An open courseware office, great diversity of content, study materials, text or the visuals in the form of normative slides.
Practice materials, case studies, problems and evaluation materials, tests and exams.
So we could say that open courseware really has limited teaching capacity, and it tends to be used as a complementary tool in open education.
So an open courseware, as was our case, tends to be the traditional starting point in open education, and after the pilot phase we ran in 2007.
We have from then onwards launched an open call every year.
We currently have 2009 courses on our site in engineering, humanities and law and social Sciences.
An we have a very limited staff and our open course in our open courseware office.
Two people with part time, dedication myself as project manager and a Technical Support person and then a person with full dedication for user support.
Understanding users as mainly the professors were working on the the platform to publish their courses.
So the only way we could really make the project sustainable 'cause we were getting around 40 proposals every year for new courses was too.
Setup or device device setup a do-it-yourself cost production model to help teachers to be a self supporting as possible in the process.
And of course we've designed the necessary tools and resources to help them with this.
More recently, we set up a quality group and one of its recent.
Initiatives.
Just this last year was to set up a peer review system to review new courses before being published on the on the OSW site.
And actually a few courses were rejected and teachers were given recommendations to improve them.
They seem to have taken this quite well and they're now working on these improvements.
These recommendations, the teachers that have done this peer review are people who already have published an OSW course.

Until either being finalists or actually won an award, an either through University University or the Open Courseware Consortium and dash lights, I could say that most of our courses are of high quality, as we've received various awards recognition.
As I say both from University and the Open Courseware Consortium.
So let's look now at the administrative OSW courses, which are actually the topic of this talk.
While horses, Vida, and another two professors from 2007 onwards have published four courses.
And what makes these courses stand out from other open courseware is the fact that they offer an enormous amount of original digital text written by the professors.
1500 pages, which actually equate to four open online textbooks, one for.
Each course as well as of course, practice materials, test case problems, exams, etc.
And these courses receive about 2000 visits per month, mainly from Spain, some from Latin America countries like Argentina, Chile, Peru, Colombia.

It's not easy to know the profile of these people, these users, but the teachers have reached some conclusions from the pattern of the visits and the keywords that people use to look for these materials.
They're mostly our own students who used the online texts as a as a textbook for their corresponding on campus course, even though they could be taught by a different a different professor.
And then also civil servants.
Well, mainly people who were applying for going to sit exams to to join the civil service.
They tend to use the practice materials and others are professors and lawyers who use the text materials for constant consultation purposes.

So the work of these professors has actually been being recognized, and in 2009 one of the courses was finalist in University Award and the next year it won one of the Consortium Awards in the text and Illustration category, and then the following year 2012 Professor Jose Vida, on behalf of the Group of Professors, actually won the Educators award for his work in in favor of the Open.
The open courseware movement.
There we go.
So let's now have a look at.

It looks as I mentioned earlier, in 2012, the Myriad X platform was launched and this has been responsible mainly for the large number of books that have been delivered or being delivered in Spain and almost at the same time at the University.
We launched the 2012 thirteen call for innovative teaching projects and as a result of this we were actually able to put three MC's on the Myriad X platform and one of these was one of the OR CW.
Administrative law courses which was actually converted to tamuk format.
So having looked at the course, let's now do a comparison of the.
Excuse me, a moment.
Yes, that's right.
Uh-huh of both models.
We've seen the open course.
We've seen the open courseware course and now we've seen the MC, so we'll do a comparison of both All CW and MC models 'cause their various different differentiating characteristics.
Ann and elements.
So basically I think one of the things that really differentiates both models is actually learning process or CW of course follows a self learning.
Method no contact with teacher.
No interaction, assessment nor set certification.
Whereas Mooks offer a more guided learning process.

Contact with teacher interaction assessment and certification, certification preparation and design of the course of course is far more demanding and a mook because it requires a specific course design.
This is minimal and or CW, just a question of adapting already existing class teaching materials as regards study materials as well.
US as well as text in MC obviously order visual materials require much greater importance.
Video lectures are needed as well as slides or divisions.
Recommendable in OSW, but it's not.
It's not a compulsory, and usually teachers just put up slides as regards, activities and assessment.
There's no correction system in open courseware.
There is of course in MC and this has to be programmed and allow for feedback.
Guarantee quality, originality, control, but I think the two main factors that differentiate both models are student monitoring and interaction, which are inexistent.
Indoor CW but totally necessary in a MC, the teacher has to supervise each stage of the course allowing for adjustments.
Maybe has to make make changes on the go and of course assessment either by test and or peer review.
And then of course tutoring students with through the forum.
And blog.
So let's look at some considerations and then in converting OSW to MC.
Well, MC scan.

Can certainly benefit from OSW materials and actually the design planning and delivery of a MC is easier if it's based on an OSW course due to the experience already acquired and the materials that have already been adapted.
Having said this, mooks should not be considered improved in version of OSW, and they've not come to take the place of open courseware.
Both models can certainly coexist.
Most certainly demand more interactive components and books out.
Of course dynamic.
They require teacher intervention as we've already, as we've already seen, right?
And some more considerations well.
The teachers that were actually involved in the experience feel it.
Obviously amook requires greater effort not only for the faculty, but also for the institution, and this is difficult to quantify.
They feel that.
Preparing, designing and delivering a mook would be the equivalent to doing the same for an on campus course for a face to face course.
But if an open courseware already exists or the course of course in open courseware format, then this can be reduced to 50%.
Then there are certain aspects that have to be taken into qua into account.
If you're looking for success, we can't approach a mook in the same way over the same content as an on campus.
Course it has to be prepared in a specific format.
The institution has to provide support staff helping the teachers with editing the text materials and with the recording and editing of the of the videos that audiovisual materials.
Of course videos have prepared well in advance that teachers have to write a script and have to rehearse it.
They have to supervise and monitor each stage of the course.
Monitoring students reactions, making changes if necessary, and then the students need to know.
There's a teacher behind the course, and it's important for the teachers to interact and put up messages in the Forum blog.
Etc So this is the result of the conversion process.
Here you can see our administrative law MC.
It ran on the Mini ADX platform during 9 weeks.
Amounted to 27 total hours of study time, with one one module module per week, and each module was comprised of four videos.
The readings, the text readings that came from the Open courseware course.
2 versions of Pepsi Presentations, a short one during the actual to be protected during the actual video, and a longer want to be downloaded as a study plan for the course.
And then the tests and assignments which came again from the Open courseware course and then of course the forum and the blog fed by the teachers.
And it's important to note.
That each assignment had to be completed before the students could go on to the next.
Fun.
So what was the result of all this?

Well, 2002 thousand students enrolled in the course, the majority from Spain, some from Latin America, which is rather surprising because law studies have intend to have a rather local focus depending on each country, students taking the book at the time were not actually studying at a degree in in law, but they were graduates who, from various backgrounds who just wanted to to learn something about the topic or.
Refresh their knowledge on the on the topic.
Others were civil servants of people preparing for the competitive competitive exams to join the civil service.
200 students actually finished the course.
Those that did so felt it being hard work and a rewarding experience.
And the teachers are of the opinion they actually obtained a solid education in law which could be equated to students enrolled in a face to face law degree program.
So what happened to the rest?
Well.
A lot dropped out during the first week due to the heavy student workload and then of course the complex assignments peer review assignment for every every module.
So what are the conclusions as we've reached well?
From this conversion process, well mixed require careful planning and design.
As we said, high level support has to be provided by the institution library and technical staff.
Books are dynamic, uncertainly require teacher intervention during course delivery.
Teachers should also take into kit into account and most can certainly affect the their work.
It could affect their academic work due to the time taken up in actually preparing, developing and delivering.
The MC could affect their open courseware courses.
They may receive less less visits if people have access to the MC and they could also affect their on campus classes.
Students might feel as less incentive to go to class if they have access to the materials or similar similar materials on the MC.
Platform.
So we could say that converting OSW two MC is a natural evolution in open education design planning.
Delivery is easier if it's based on open open courseware due to the experience required and the materials that have already been developed.
Moocs have not come to take the place of OSW.
Both models can coexist and be offered simultaneously, because they both tend to reach looking to reach different target audiences because they offer different education experiences.
Self learning versus guided learning.

Both or CW Repositor Zahn books are showcases of the university's academic programs and the quality of its teaching moves come closer to on campus courses then OSW due to the unique, unique characteristics, the guided learning and a specific time the teacher, student interaction, and the assessment and accreditation moves are certainly a better way to attract future.
Potential students, but at the same time it's very important that they should offer a solid and useful learning experience to those who cannot afford it.
So thank you very much.

I just like to say that an I'm not extended version of our paper has been published in the Open Praxis Journal, so you have it there at your disposal if you'd like to read more about this experience, OK, so thank you and I'd be happy to answer any questions or hear any comments, or if people have had similar experiences, the floor is yours.
The how do you combine the the dropout rate and the pure evaluation?

Is there risks was difficult to the to avoid the frustration of somebody not having anybody, anybody to evaluate, or was the evaluation done sufficiently late in the process that you knew that the people were going to be doing the evaluation?
Well, not sure if I understood you correctly by percentages here, unless the evaluation was done in what way the peer evaluation that might.
Also this was like a practice case.
The students had to have to solve.
Had to write like an essay.
We could say an assignment OK and then using the actual peer review in two of the mini ADX platform it was distributed between two or three people.
OK and this had to be done.
Every week, and as I said, students could go only go on to the next module if they done the peer review of the of that that week's module.
So it was quite a heavy workload, and in a strict program, and it was obviously too much for many people who who dropped out.
Answer your question.
OK, thank you.
Usually marks is has a much shorter time compared with the usual 18 weeks, which is about like 6 to 10 weeks, 9 weeks, 9 weeks, 9 weeks.
Yeah, so is there any I mean.
Studies that why shorter is better, or I mean basically what would be the maximum length of one can try to print or make it more flexible.
For instance, if I cook up a life plan or MC course which is like 12 week long, would that really I mean improve the presentation or it would dramatically kill the flexibility of milk?
So I'm curious about this.
Learn things and I wonder whether you can have some coming on 30 years, but why it wasn't a nine week program is actually?
Is there scientific proof or evidence?
Or it just happens?
That way?
I think it just happens.
I think it was also one of the recommendations of Maryada.
Perhaps you're thinking that maybe if it been like a 12 week program, the modules could have been spread out.
More students could have had more time and maybe they wouldn't have been such a high dropout rate.
Is that what you're aiming at?
1.1 possibility I think, just because that's what we've seen that.
Do you know the the majority of books are quite quite short, or at least it on the on the Myriad X platform.
It was one of the recommendations and actually now that I think about it, the first series of books on the Myriad X platform we're actually aiming at winning an award and it was very.
I mean, it was a very strict yes.
That was the way to launch the platform and to get professors to take part.
For the first time in this experience of preparing and delivering a book.
And so there was a very strict you know schedule calendar.
OK, so as I remember now, haha.
That was like the maximum 9 weeks.

But that doesn't mean to say that if this book was delivered again on a different platform, of course the teachers could, from the results from the high dropout rate, could maybe consider extending the program and reducing the workload each week.
It's something to take into consideration.
One of the last recommend conclusions was that MC, Scoot or shoot or would serve as a sort of advertising for a classical courses.
Is it?
Is this supported?
The one before last?
Is it supported by some hard evidence or is it your wish or conjecture?
Because I find this very interesting, I don't think it's supported by any specific or concrete evidence.
I would say it's just it's the feeling that we have is the same with open courseware.
Putting up teaching materials on the on the open courseware site is obviously a showcase for University away to attract future on campus students and the SANE.
And it's even more so with the MC.
We think because, as I said, an MC format.
It is more similar to an on campus course than in the case of OSW, but we haven't done any any research into this, no.
Last question.

I notice that you have a high degree of faculty participation in open courseware courses, and I'm curious if the possibility the book offering has changed that faculty interest in those courses and how you talk to them about the differences between the two.
You're interested in how he was sorry.
How do you talk to the faculty about the differences between the open courseware opportunity and the MC opportunity?
Huh?
Well, I have to say that at my University and I think this is unfortunate.
Both projects are quite kept quite separate open courseware and mook.
I talked to the professors that have sent proposals for the yearly open call.
I talked to the mall at the beginning of the year and tell them all about open courseware and what's in.
You know what they're facing, etc cetera, etc.
As regards the MC, this follows a different process, an we've just launched an open call for proposals for books to be put up on the edx platform.
There's been a seminar to inform the professors about.
How to do this?
The support that will be available etc and the call is just closed.
So when I go back maybe I'll find out what.

What are the four proposal for teachers that have been that have been chosen but an as I say they are kept separate, but the support that the administrative staff gives comes basically from this educational technology innovative teaching unit.
Which I'm also part of the Langley I wear.
Normally they open courseware hat.
So basically it all stems from the same like support service.
OK, but as I say, both projects are run independently and we've only had the one case of converting an open courseware course into MC.
I hope to be more in the future.
Thank you, thank you, thank you again, this speaker.
